criteria.main: Persistent inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity interfering with functioning or development
other_requirements: Not better explained by another disorder

duration_requirement: ≥6 months, inconsistent with developmental level, negative functional impact. For ages 17+, ≥5 symptoms required.

specifiers.remission: Partial remission possible if fewer criteria met but impairment remains

criteria.main: Chronic fluctuating mood disturbance with numerous periods of hypomanic and depressive symptoms not meeting full episode criteria.

hypomanic_symptoms: Numerous periods of hypomanic symptoms that do not meet criteria for a hypomanic episode
depressive_symptoms: Numerous periods of depressive symptoms that do not meet criteria for a major depressive episode

other_requirements: Symptoms present for ≥2 years in adults (≥1 year in children/adolescents)
Symptoms present at least half the time, no symptom-free period longer than 2 months
Criteria for major depressive, manic, or hypomanic episode never met
Not better explained by schizophrenia spectrum/psychotic disorders
Not attributable to substance or medical condition
Causes clinically significant distress or impairment

duration_requirement: At least 2 years in adults (1 year in children/adolescents), with symptoms present at least half the time and no symptom-free interval longer than 2 months.
common_treatments: Atypical antipsychotics (for mood stabilization in some cases)
Psychoeducation and lifestyle management (regular sleep, stress reduction, structured routines)

criteria: Inability to recall important autobiographical information, usually of a traumatic or stressful nature, inconsistent with ordinary forgetting.
Symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
Not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., alcohol, drug, medication) or a neurological/medical condition (e.g., seizures, traumatic brain injury).
Not better explained by other disorders such as dissociative identity disorder, PTSD, acute stress disorder, somatic symptom disorder, or neurocognitive disorder.

specifiers.with_dissociative_fugue: Purposeful travel or bewildered wandering associated with amnesia for identity or autobiographical information.

duration_requirement: No fixed minimum duration; episodes may last minutes to decades. Onset can be sudden or delayed, often after trauma.
forms: Localized amnesia: inability to recall events during a circumscribed period.
Selective amnesia: recall of some but not all events in a circumscribed period.
Generalized amnesia: rare; loss of entire life history and identity.
Systematized amnesia: loss of memory for a specific category (e.g., family, abuse).
Continuous amnesia: ongoing inability to form or retain new memories.
associated_features: Histories of trauma, child abuse, victimization.
Dissociative flashbacks, self-mutilation, suicide attempts, high-risk behaviors.
Depression, functional neurological symptoms, depersonalization, high hypnotizability.
Sexual dysfunctions, possible mild traumatic brain injury preceding onset.

risk_factors.genetic_and_physiological: No specific genetic studies; dissociation has both genetic and environmental influences.

development_and_course: Onset may be sudden (especially generalized amnesia). Episodes can be single or recurrent, lasting minutes to decades. Memories may return gradually or suddenly, sometimes with PTSD-like flashbacks. Dissociative capacity may decline with age.
culture_related_issues: In some regions (Asia, Middle East, Latin America), may present with non-epileptic seizures or functional neurological symptoms. Triggers may be psychological stresses rather than trauma in restrictive cultures.
suicide_risk: Elevated, particularly when memories return suddenly and overwhelm the individual.
functional_consequences: Ranges from limited impairment (localized amnesia) to severe vocational and interpersonal disability (generalized amnesia).
differential_diagnosis: Posttraumatic Amnesia due to Brain Injury
comorbidity: Depressive disorders (major depressive disorder, dysthymia, adjustment disorders).
Somatic symptom disorders and conversion disorder.
common_treatments: Hypnosis or medication-assisted interviews (e.g., barbiturate-facilitated) in some cases to recover memories.
Treatment of comorbid conditions (e.g., depression, PTSD).
Supportive therapy to improve coping, relationships, and reduce distress.
Crisis intervention and suicide prevention when needed.
